body: Just submitted a PR for this. I focused primarily on removing duplicate code, but I also cleaned up some of the comments and restructured the code to make it more readable overall. If any of my changes went too far, let me know.
Really great pull request @lbschanno .  Nice re-factoring.
@jzgithub1 thanks!
I'll take a look.

@ctubbsii I think I have a fix for this but do I check this into 2.0 or just master?
I haven't pushed a fix to a branch other than master before.

> Maybe to best this is to remove the "warning message"

Could also log it at debug instead of removing it.
A pull request against 2.0 is best for this one. When you open the pull request, GitHub offers a drop-down, where you can select to submit against the 2.0 branch.

You can update this PR to point to the 2.0 branch by following these steps:

* Select "Edit" on this pull request and select the 2.0 branch from the "base" dropdown,
* Then run the following locally:

```bash
# ensure your remotes are up-to-date
git remote update --prune
# checkout your branch locally
# (these instructions assume "origin" points to github.com/hkeebler/accumulo
#  and assume "upstream" points to github.com/apache/accumulo)
git checkout -t origin/accumulo-1272
# reset the local branch to the 2.0 base
git reset --hard upstream/2.0
# grab the commit from the head of the feature branch and put it onto the new 2.0 base
git cherry-pick origin/accumulo-1272
# force-push to clobber your feature branch (and update the PR)
# this will test; remove "--dry-run" to actually execute
git push -f --dry-run
```
I added instructions on PR #1274 to change the current PR to 2.0.
okay, I think i did this as requested.  thank you.

If they are created by the bulk import code itself, it definitely shouldn't give warnings about files it creates itself, but we don't want to lower the warning to "DEBUG" if it sees other unexpected files.

I don't know who created these files, or if they have a choice to put them elsewhere. Are these files created by the bulk import code or the testing code?
Bulk import creates the loadmap.json file.    We could create a list of "expected files to ignore" but would need to figure out what they all are.
Thanks for the quick review.  I'll address all your responses.
#1255 is related
Requested changes pushed except for renaming `codecClazz` arg due to requesting clarification.
@keith-turner What tests were you running when getting these results? I want to see if I can reproduce these so I can get to the bottom of it.
I am not sure, but probably continuous ingest.  Possibly with tablet server agitation.
I will work on this.

I suspect that splitting could have been a cause for this issue.  Yesterday I ran a test importing 100 directories into a table with a small split threshold (32M).  This caused a lot of splits to happen while the imports were running.  I did not see any problems.  I am currently running a test to import 1000 directories with agitation incorporating some of the recent changes.  I opened apache/accumulo-testing#94 because generating the 1000 dirs for import takes quite a while.

In TabletTime `public static String maxMetadataTime(String mv1, String mv2)` should probably be updated to use MetadataTime objects instead of string but that is for another ticket I think.  Additionally, a MetadataTimeTest was added and the TabletTimeTest updated to remove duplicate tests.

The travis builds are failing with the following message.

```
The job exceeded the maximum log length, and has been terminated.
```

@lbschanno thanks for the contribution.  If you would like to be added as a contributor on the website, please edit the following and submit a PR.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo-website/edit/master/pages/people.md

> should probably be updated to use MetadataTime objects instead of string but that is for another ticket 

That sounds good.  Definitely good to avoid putting too much into a single PR.  I like to make sure I open issues for all follow on work identified in a PR before closing it so I don't forget about it.

> a MetadataTimeTest was added and the TabletTimeTest updated to remove duplicate tests.

@hkeebler  I am not seeing the MetadataTimeTest

The TServer adds metrics by taking the size of an `.entrySet()` (which is an `int`) to a `double`, so it can be the divisor for the total time taken in millis (which is a `long`), presumably so it can keep some precision in the division, before it casts to a long to return the result.

I see two possibilities:

1. The entry set was empty, and casting it to a `0` to a double resulted in something very large when placing this "very close to, but not quite zero" value in the denominator, or
2. The system clock was updated and caused a bigger than expected time difference in millis when using `System.currentTimeMillis()`.

I think option 1 is more likely. We should probably guard against the set being empty before adding a metrics.

There are two methods that do this: https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/ebca8e13dd12fc866887ebbd773ceeacb69a2f3e/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/TabletServer.java#L1156-L1162

This is all just rounding issues, but if I'm right, and the size was zero, what probably happened is that no mutations were queued on line:
https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/ebca8e13dd12fc866887ebbd773ceeacb69a2f3e/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/TabletServer.java#L1091
This should be a simple fix for 2.0. We just return in the above methods if `(size < 1)`.

This is intended as a replacement for `ListLexicoder`. Delegating to it would seem to defeat that purpose. 
Additionally, prefixing the non-empty list encodings with a single byte would have a slight negative impact on the performance of lexicographical sorts, as well have undesirable effects on any rowids generated using it (affecting splits and shell output), as the overwhelming majority of encoded values (i.e., every non-empty list) would have the same first byte. Marking non-empty lists with a trailing byte, which this implementation does, avoids these (small but nonetheless annoying) issues.

In any case, I don't think delegating to `ListLexicoder` would have as much of a "simplifying" effect on the implementation as you think it does, since the byte would still need to be added before encoding, removed prior to decoding, with appropriate checks added to validate that nothing unexpected is in the data. For this implementation, I just started from the existing implementation of `ListLexicoder` and added the appropriate changes to handle empty lists, then applied a few optimizations, validations, and general cleanup to make it a bit more robust. I also modified the implementation of `ListLexicoder` to validate that it isn't applied to empty lists. Delegating to it would mean an unnecessary check would be taking place on data that was already validated. It would also necessitate an otherwise unneeded array copy after invoking `ListLexicoder.encode` to order to add the prefix/suffix byte, whereas this implementation avoids that.
Standard formatting applied as requested.

> This is intended as a replacement for `ListLexicoder`. Delegating to it would seem to defeat that purpose.

No, they can still share implementation, where it makes sense to do so.

> Additionally, prefixing the non-empty list encodings with a single byte would have a slight negative impact...

Agreed. You're right. Putting the "empty/not-empty" marker at the end is better than at the beginning.

> In any case, I don't think delegating to ListLexicoder would have as much of a "simplifying" effect on the implementation...

I'm merely suggesting a slight refactor to use a common implementation to decode after checking the input array length when decoding, and to use a common implementation to encode prior to appending a marker when encoding. A common implementation should be possible, given that the only difference between the two would be the presence of an additional marker byte at the end (which is ignored, and present only to distinguish from the empty case where length == 0).

Most of the heavy lifting is already being done by the `ByteUtils.concat` and `ByteUtils.split` methods, which are called by both implementations, effectively providing the common implementation. There isn't much else that is really shareable between the two classes, due to subtle differences in how they handle the ends of the lists, as well as the validation checks that they do, at least not without sacrificing efficiency. The `SequenceLexicoder.decodeUnchecked` method is only longer than the equivalent method in `ListLexicoder` because I added some sanity checks and split out some chained function calls that were all on one line in `ListLexicoder` into multiple lines in `SequenceLexicoder` for the sake of code clarity. I could have done the same for `ListLexicoder`, but didn't want to modify code that I wasn't altering the behavior of.

On a side note, the automated "standard" formatting did some truly horrifying things to a few parts of the code, like splitting

```java
assert escapedElements.length > 0 : "ByteUtils.split always returns a minimum of 1 element, even for empty input";
```

into

```java
assert escapedElements.length
        > 0 : "ByteUtils.split always returns a minimum of 1 element, even for empty input";
```

Who inserts a line break into the middle of a numeric comparison? ;-)

> Most of the heavy lifting is already being done by the `ByteUtils.concat` and `ByteUtils.split` methods, which are called by both implementations, effectively providing the common implementation. There isn't much else that is really shareable between the two classes...

Okay, that's fair. If there's something we can think of later to deduplicate common code, it can be done later, as a follow-on.

The main differences between your implementation and my proposed one is that yours adds an extra delimiter on the end (via the concat method), even in the case of an empty list, whereas my suggestion wouldn't add one when the list is empty. But, either way is probably fine.

> ...the automated "standard" formatting did some truly horrifying things...

Agreed. That kind of stuff has been bothering me a bit, too. I recently changed some of the formatting rules to support Java 11 and to wrap more aggressively in some cases, but the rules probably still need some more tweaking.

Our formatting rules are based on the Eclipse JDT formatter, used by the formatter-maven-plugin, and the config is located at: https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/master/contrib/Eclipse-Accumulo-Codestyle.xml ; feel free to open a PR to change the config or discuss on the mailing list any proposals you might have to improve the formatting. Just keep in mind that it's more important that we converge on a ruleset that can be automatically enforced, even if it's slightly inferior aesthetically, so changes should be within the capabilities of the JDT formatter.
Sorry, test should be there now.
@lbschanno noticed that I need to make the MetadataTime class final to truly make it immutable. So I will make that change but hold back a new push for any additional comments.  Thanks @lbschanno
Pull request available for review.

so...based on the 'like' should I look into implementing the "expected files" set?

BulkImport.filterInvalid(FileStatus[] files) does exactly what you are looking for.  Just have to figure out how to use it in the Prep

> The main differences between your implementation and my proposed one is that yours adds an extra delimiter on the end (via the concat method), even in the case of an empty list, whereas my suggestion wouldn't add one when the list is empty. But, either way is probably fine.
> 

No, it doesn't. An empty list is encoded as an empty byte array. There will only be a delimiter if there is at least one element. A single empty element will be encoded as a single delimiter byte.

The implementation of `ByteUtils.concat`  uses this block at the end of the field loop to insert delimiters:
```java
if (index < ret.length)
   ret[index++] = 0x00;
```
If `if` effectively prevents the loop from adding a delimiter to the end of the list, since the length of `ret` is determined by the expression `len + fields.length - 1` (where `len` is the sum of the encoded field lengths, and `fields.length - 1` gives the number of delimiters). In the case of an empty list, `concat` will be called with a single (empty) field, so no delimiters will be added.

@hkeebler I haven't looked into it enough to know what the refactor should look like, but it would make sense for the checks in the master/fate code to be consistent with those in the clientImpl. However, looking at the change in #1255 , I'm not sure it's a good idea to have *all* unknown files logged at `debug`. I think some actually warrant `warn`.

There appear to be a few different file types and each probably requires a different action:

1. Expected files to bulk import: `*.rf`. (I'm not even sure we support map files anymore)
2. Directories (do we recurse or log that we're ignoring? I'm not sure the current behavior)
3. Well-known files that are not ours, but common from MapReduce and safe to ignore (`_SUCCESS`,  `_logs`?); logging these at debug probably makes sense
4. Files we create ourselves (or expect the user to provide): JSON loadmap files or rename mapping files; these can be ignored or we could log (at debug) that we're using them when we actually read them.
5. Completely unknown files that are not expected or typical. These should probably log at the `warn` level.

And I :+1: 'd your previous comment primarily because I think you correctly identified step 1: `figure out what they all are` :smiley_cat:

> No, it doesn't. An empty list is encoded as an empty byte array. There will only be a delimiter if there is at least one element. A single empty element will be encoded as a single delimiter byte.

Okay. I see that now. I guess I wasn't thinking clearly. Thanks for clarifying. :smiley_cat:

It becomes more clear to me when I write it out as a grammar:
```
SEQUENCE → ( ESCAPED_ELEM DELIM )* EMPTY
LIST → ( ESCAPED_ELEM DELIM )* ESCAPED_ELEM
```
Based on a "refactor" of the process should this be moved to 2.1, not hold back 2.0 release.
I'll add those changes and do some quick testing, doubt I can reproduce this bug consistently enough to guarantee it being fixed

After running some of the Bulk load IT tests I saw that it also created a hidden version of files - prefixed with a "." and extension ".crc".  We could filter out hidden files or just extension .crc?  I could see that advantages to the former is in the future we could make any working files hidden files.
The previous comment is specific to the SharedMiniClusterBase.  I'm unable to find a current test that will exercise the code on a real instance.
@hkeebler I can merge this after you add `final` to metadata time.

> The previous comment is specific to the SharedMiniClusterBase.

I think that is the behavior of the Hadoop LocalFilesystem.   I suspect when you are listing files using the LocalFilesystem APIs you will never see these crc files.  May only see them when doing `ls`.  

The Hadoop distributed filesystem also computes crcs for blocks and stores them on the local filesystem.  When you poke around in a datanodes local dir you will see them.
This is ready.  Note I did not squash the commit messages due to your previous request.
Used the accumulo-testing cingest bulk to test this and did not receive any messages of "crc" files.  The approach I suggested will likely cover everything for now.
This was seen while analyzing the test run mentioned in #1277
I opened apache/accumulo-testing#98 with some info about checking the counts after a test.

I added some unit tests for `TabletMutationPrepAttempt`. If you like, I will also tackle adding some unit tests for the modifications to `Tablet.prepareMutationsForCommit` if they are not already covered by another test.

A refactor might cause things to wait until 2.1, but I think it'd be good if we could clean up the user experience here for 2.0... bulk ingest is pretty important for Accumulo, and spamming the logs with unnecessary entries will be a big pain point for users.
Ignore the next set of changes. Ran into some small issues changing the base to 2.0. Hopefully everything is in order now.
fyi - I recall, when running the examples having similar issues and the uno version would default to 2.0-alpha... It was necessary to explicitly point uno to my 2.0.0-SNAPSHOT build.
I ran another 1000 dir bulk import & agitation test with these changes and it was successful.

What verison of Hadoop are you running?

What example are you following?  The examples in 1.9 are all baked into the Accumulo release.  The example you are looking at follows this example here: https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.3/docs/src/main/resources/examples/README.bulkIngest

I'm definitely interested in how hard it would be to backport the procedure described in [bulk-test.md](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing/blob/master/docs/bulk-test.md)  from [accumulo-testing/master](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing/tree/master) to [accumulo-testing/1.9](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing/tree/1.9) that might be a better/more comprehensive test.

> I'm definitely interested in how hard it would be to backport the procedure described in [bulk-test.md](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing/blob/master/docs/bulk-test.md) from [accumulo-testing/master](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing/tree/master) to [accumulo-testing/1.9](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing/tree/1.9) that might be a better/more comprehensive test.

That might not be too bad.  The bulk ingest command works with both versions:

```importdirectory /tmp/bt/$i/files true```
- is actually using the new bulk import technique.

```importdirectory /tmp/bt/$i/files /tmp/failure_directory true```
- would use the legacy bulk import.

I had hoped that it wouldn't break binary compatibility with more recent releases, but I didn't have time to check last night. I'll see if I can avoid that error, but if not, are you okay with breaking binary compatibility across a major version so we clean up the cruft moving forward?

hadoop_version = 2.8.4
zookeeper_version = 3.4.14
accumulo_version = 1.9.3


I did a sanity check on the instructions you pointed out on a fresh cluster

History:
PKG=org.apache.accumulo.examples.simple.mapreduce.bulk
ARGS="-i muchos -z <> -u <> -p <>"
cd install/accumulo-1.9.3/
./bin/accumulo $PKG.SetupTable $ARGS -t test_bulk row_00000333 row_00000666
./bin/accumulo $PKG.GenerateTestData --start-row 0 --count 1000 --output bulk/test_1.txt
./bin/tool.sh lib/accumulo-examples-simple.jar $PKG.BulkIngestExample $ARGS -t test_bulk --inputDir bulk --workDir tmp/bulkWork
SUCCESS

History:
accumulo org.apache.accumulo.examples.simple.mapreduce.bulk.GenerateTestData --start-row 0 --count 1000 --output gen/test.txt
accumulo org.apache.accumulo.examples.simple.mapreduce.bulk.BulkIngestExample -i muchos -u root -p <> -t test_bulk --inputDir gen --workDir tmp/bulk
FAILURE


The latter was the one failing. So using the proper JAR results in success.

Closing the issue, user error

> are you okay with breaking binary compatibility across a major version so we clean up the cruft moving forward?

Personally,  I would leave those methods and maybe adjust the comment.  My reason for leaving them is that I think it has the potential to waste users time in a very confusing way.  I don't see any harm in leaving the existing decode methods with proper comments because the code is extremely stable and no one ever touches it.

It looks like it can't be done without breaking binary compatibility. However, it was previously documented to be removed in 2.0 (because major versions are the versions in which binary compatibility breaking would be more tolerable). Are you okay with binary compatibility breakage here? Or should we keep these concrete methods indefinitely? (If the latter, we should update the comments at least, since they wouldn't be removed in 2.0).

Either way, I should be able to keep the removal of the non-public types.
Didn't see your comment, @keith-turner , before posting my last one. I'll restore the removed methods and update the comments.

Silently succeeding would be surprising behavior, because importing an empty directory is almost certainly a mistake on the user's part (typo: wrong directory specified). But, the above is very unfriendly, so a nice clear error message in the client would be nice.
One option would be to WARN on the client and then just pass through the server, succeeding.
I am leaning twoards succeeding on an empty directory because it makes it easier for user to write idempotent code.
I'm just glad I now know what that error messages means.  Thanks.
@keith-turner How's these changes now?
I like the idea of an explicit parameter and I think that would be easy to do in the Java API.  Not sure about the shell.

> I like the idea of an explicit parameter and I think that would be easy to do in the Java API. Not sure about the shell.

Should be easy enough to add a shell option, `--ignore-empty`
Could make empty dir fail in 2.0 and open a 2.1 issue to add API and shell options to ignore empty.

> Should be easy enough to add a shell option, --ignore-empty

Just have to consider that the shell may call the old or new API and think through how this option would work with both.

> Could make empty dir fail in 2.0 and open a 2.1 issue to add API and shell options to ignore empty.

:+1: That would get us closer to 2.0 release faster.

As for the makeRelative code... it's a bit tricky. What we're doing here is normalizing the paths to effectively trim out the volume information, so that we don't unintentionally delete a file that was still in use. We want to detect that a file is still in use, even if it looks like it's on a different volume... because it could look like it's on a different volume because of many weird scenarios (such as hostname of the HDFS volume changing or being remapped).

At one point, we assumed all files were on a single HDFS volume, so all paths in the metadata were "relative" to some root volume (specified by `instance.dfs.uri`, but defaulting to Hadoop's `fs.defaultFS`) and directory (specified by `instance.dfs.dir`, defaulting to `/accumulo`). Old metadata can still be written that way, but new data should be written with the full volume and absolute path to the file in HDFS, because we now support running on top of multiple HDFS volumes (like mounting different disks, say `/dev/sda` and `/dev/sdb`). So, we need to store more than just the relative paths.

I hope that helps provide some context for this confusing code. Specifically what it's doing to normalize... I'd have to look at it more carefully, but I think all of it can be ignored for the purposes of this ticket. What matters here is that we have a distinct prefix (to replace the current `~del`), and we normalize whatever we have left after we strip off the prefix.

Thanks @ctubbsii for the explanation.  It helps explain why the test is using relative path where I though absolutes should be expected.  The above mentioned method throws an IllegalArgumentException if parsing the path doesn't appear as it should.  Why would this ever occur?  This is controlled/generated data.

> Why would this ever occur?

`IllegalStateException` is probably more appropriate, since it isn't user-provided. This can occur if data gets corrupted, or if we have a bug, or if users were performing manual surgery on the metadata table to recover from a failure and made a mistake. It really shouldn't ever happen, but if it does, we probably want the accumulo-gc service to die from the RuntimeException, rather than potentially delete files that it shouldn't.
